subject: Re: [junit] Looking for some "Best Practices"
msgSnippet: ... I reduce the programming overhead associated with writing unit tests by writing more unit tests. OK, that was a bit obtuse.  My experience indicates that
messageBody:
Vikas Malla wrote:

>1) What efforts have you guys taken in your respective organizations to reduce the programming overhead associated with writing unit tests?
>

I reduce the programming overhead associated with writing unit tests by
writing more unit tests.

OK, that was a bit obtuse. My experience indicates that writing
effective tests first reduces the overall programming overhead. That
is, I write less production code because the designs that emerge by
satisfying tests tend to be simpler with less code. It also generally
takes less code to make these designs respond to change. Moreover, I'm
only writing code that a customer really needs today. So, in the big
pot theory of economics, I've found writing unit tests to be underhead,
if there is such a thing.


>2) What are the tools you use for creation of unit tests, if any?
>

I don't mean to be flippant, but the tool encased by my cranium has
proven to be the most valuable. It's able to ask and answer questions
like: "What is this chunk of code supposed to do?" Then I just use an
editor (Eclipse) to reify the question and answer in code. As a
convenience, I have a template in Eclipse that lays down the boilerplate
code for a test case.


>3) Do you prefer using tools for unit tests creation?
>
Tools can be useful and productive to automate things, though I prefer
to understand how to do those things manually first. I'm then free from
the bondage of a tool, which is often handy when visiting projects that
use different tools. That is, the absence of a tool never stands in my
way of writing tests.

If you're referring to tools that purport to automatically write tests
by inspecting code, then I have used those as a supplement to unit tests
I write. Used as a sole means for testing, I miss the opportunity for
better designs. I've found automatic test generators to be especially
helpful when faced with refactoring legacy code for which no tests
exist. It's better than no tests at all.

>4) We use JBuilder in our development efforst. What would you advise us to go for to reduce our development overheads associated with unit tests?
>

When and how are you writing tests now? To what extent is that
incurring an overhead?

>5) What do you guys think of cactus?
>

It's an excellent tool if you really must test components fronted by a
web application in their native environment. If you start swinging the
Cactus golden hammer too early, then it's been my experience that soon
everything indeed must be tested within the container. I strive to
never use it, focusing instead on building modular components that can
be tested outside of the container. Components of this sort then don't
depend on the container, and the technology implied therein. So,
although Cactus is well-designed and scratches certain itches, using it
should be an exception, not the rule.

Hope this helps. Please ask for clarification on any of these answers
if they don't make sense.

Mike
